descriptionNullable:
Since the declaration of COVID 19 pandemic by the WHO, health care workers worldwide
experienced a great deal of stresses particularly due to the unknown behavior of the
pathogen and the high rate of infection among HCWs. The mental health toll the virus has
taken on the globe affects the health care workers in many folds which is reflected by
mounting evidence on high levels of anxiety, depression, and stress among HCW (Spoorthy
et al. 2020) (Takahiro et al 2020) (Heesakkers et al. 2021). According to Lai et al (2020),
health care workers assigned for COVID care, were likely to develop symptoms of anxiety,
depression, insomnia, and distress. Moreover, the psychological distress among HCW during
a pandemic of current nature, is attributed to: being parents of dependent children, being
junior in service, longer quarantine period, lack of practical support and stigma (Kisely et al
2020). Acknowledging the issue of psychological burden on HCW, the World Health
Organization has published guidelines to support health care workers in care settings (WHO
2020).
title: Burnout in COVID 19' Healthcare Personnel
description:
